While I am happy to read about the approval of the Spanish law "Solo sí es sí" that finally recognises the importance of affirmative consent, lawmakers are leaving behind the right to consent of sex workers by stigmatising the porn industry, yet again. 1/2 https://t.co/CMKJsto4IV

Barcelona! Nos vemos hoy en La Central del Raval ❣️ https://t.co/6ao16BGESC
By condemning the porn industry without taking all of these aspects into account, this bill only reinforces the stigma on sex workers and confuses sex work with sex trafficking.
"Sex work is only safe when it is decriminalised, and pornography is artistic expression and thus a right under freedom of speech." - @PaulitaPappel

If the government really cares about women's rights, they should ask how women are treated in the porn industry? Are these women entirely in charge of their own careers? How can we guarantee the basic labor rights of sex workers?

What is presented as an effort to stop exploitation and violence in defence of human rights, in particular women's rights, ends up being the main source of violence, precariousness and lack of protection for all sex workers - who are already vulnerable as it is.

According to the political parties behind this bill, it would not matter whether the practice is carried out under exploitation -banned under current law- or if it is independent labor, with consent from all parties involved, following ethical production standards.
The proposed amendment by PSOE, as it is right now, calls for the abolition of all forms of making a profit from the prostitution of others, including porn production.

This International Sex Workers Day, I want to take the opportunity to express my unconditional support to all sex performers currently based in Spain, where the government is once again threatening their safety with prohibitionist bills that claim to 'protect their rights'.

There is one specific group we tend to shut out the most from the conversation when it comes to self-pleasure: our kids. To encourage my fellow parents out there, I am sharing my top tips  on how to talk to your kids about masturbation on Lust Zine https://t.co/KV5v2QvZCA

"Sex work is only safe when it is decriminalised, and pornography is artistic expression and thus a right under freedom of speech." - @PaulitaPappel

If the government really cares about women's rights, they should ask how women are treated in the porn industry? Are these women entirely in charge of their own careers? How can we guarantee the basic labor rights of sex workers?

What is presented as an effort to stop exploitation and violence in defence of human rights, in particular women's rights, ends up being the main source of violence, precariousness and lack of protection for all sex workers - who are already vulnerable as it is.

According to the political parties behind this bill, it would not matter whether the practice is carried out under exploitation -banned under current law- or if it is independent labor, with consent from all parties involved, following ethical production standards.
The proposed amendment by PSOE, as it is right now, calls for the abolition of all forms of making a profit from the prostitution of others, including porn production.

This International Sex Workers Day, I want to take the opportunity to express my unconditional support to all sex performers currently based in Spain, where the government is once again threatening their safety with prohibitionist bills that claim to 'protect their rights'.
